title: Desperate Housewives star Felicity Huffman leaves prison after 11 days
text:
Felicity Huffman has been released from prison (Picture: AP)

Felicity Huffman has left prison early after only serving 11 days of her 14-day sentence.

The Desperate Housewives actress still has to perform 250 hours of community service; she has already paid a $30,000 (£23,800) fine.

Felicity, 56, pleaded guilty in the shocking college admissions scandal, admitting to paying $15,000 (£12,100) to doctor daughter Sophia’s university entrance exams.

It is thought she was released early because the Federal Correction Institution in Dublin, California has a policy that allows inmates to leave on Friday if their scheduled release date falls on a weekend.

Prosecutors had asked for a month in prison and a $20,000 (£15,900) fine.

Felicity Huffman, escorted by her husband actor William H. Macy (Picture: AP)

Judge Indira Talwani told Felicity at the sentencing: ‘I don’t think anyone wants to be going to prison.

‘I do think this is the right sentence here. You move forward and you can rebuild your life after this. You pay your dues.’

Felicity also spoke at the hearing and said: ‘I am deeply sorry to the students, parents, colleges and universities who have been impacted by my actions.

‘I am sorry to my daughter, Sophia, my daughter, Georgia, and my husband, Bill. I have betrayed them all.’

Eva Longoria and Felicity Huffman both starred on Desperate Housewives (Picture: Wireimage)

Over 50 people were charged including parents and athletic coaches; none of the children were indicted.

Huffman’s husband William H. Macy was not indicted either.

The 69-year-old actor was one of 27 of Felicity’s nearest and dearest to submit a letter to the judge presiding over her case ahead of sentencing, revealing that her relationship with her daughter’s had now deteriorated.

Lori Loughlin has pleaded not guilty (Picture: AP)

On 23 October a notice from the US Department of Justice confirmed that Lori Loughlin, who was also caught up in the scandal, and her husband were both facing an additional charge each of conspiracy to commit federal programs bribery – the theft or bribery of an organisation that receives more than $10,000 (£7,777) in federal funds.

The charge carries a penalty of up to 10 years in federal prison.

As well as this, the couple – parents to Olivia Jade and Bella – had already been facing charges of money laundering conspiracy, conspiracy to commit mail and wire fraud, and honest services mail and wire fraud.

If found guilty on all counts, they could be behind bars for around 50 years.

They both pleaded not guilty to all charges, and are awaiting trial after turning down a plea deal that involved jail time.
